More on the proposal here: https://tipton.house.gov/colorado-rec-act …

The #ColoradoRECAct is intended to balance the unique needs and desires of various stakeholders that I have met with in recent years, and I hope to be able to build broad consensus around this bill as it moves through the legislative process.

The draft proposal would:

Conserve pristine wilderness areas in the San Juan and Sange de Cristos by over 70,000 acres

Formally establish the Curecanti National Recreation Area

Enhance recreation opportunities at the Yucca House National Monument by adding 160 acres

Colorado's Third Congressional District is home to some of our nation's most cherished public lands. I look forward to continue the conversations I've held on how to best manage those lands and receiving feedback to improve upon my draft legislation. #ColoradoRECact pic.twitter.com/ieNz1f1PTg

America needs a robust All-of-the-above energy strategy to meet the needs of our families, not a ‘neutral stance.’ Jordan Cove has had support from both sides of the isle in the past, and its importance to Colorado and the rest of the world cannot be overstated.
It is creates a market for Russians and other adversaries to export to countries with no intentions to reduce pollution.
It fails to replace the AVERAGE $91,000 salary jobs that tens of thousands of Coloradan families rely on.
It ignores the fact that done responsibly, LNG actually reduces the carbon emissions and pollution outputted from older traditional fuel burning power sources.
It cuts off funding for schools, roads, and other necessary local community resources.
For starters, it’s a disservice to the Western Slope residents who understand the potential the Piceance Basin, our country’s 2nd largest natural gas reserve, could have on the economy.

Like all my CO colleagues, I too enjoy our open spaces and am dedicated to protecting them, but the 3rd District is more than just Denver's playground. The CORE Act would significantly impact many areas there and doesn't have the consensus needed to go further in the leg. process

As with any public lands bill, the CORE Act has a lot of ideas that most Coloradans agree on but it largely ignores many voices from the district it primarily would impact: mine.

My full statement: https://bit.ly/31YhOQ4

#TBT: How to Pass a Wilderness Bill in 2014 (not much changed in 2019)
 https://bit.ly/332h2mo 

How did CORE Act compare?

❌ Give yourself plenty of time⏰
❌ Be prepared to offer more than just wilderness 🌲
❌ Be willing to compromise 🤝
❌ Be prepared for setbacks 🥾🔙

Today, I am still not assured that my constituent's voices have been heard, nor their concerns adequately addressed in the CORE Act.  I am optimistic that through compromise, proper outreach and further collaboration, we can build that consensus. More work needs to be done.

Club 20:
"While we understand that the CORE Act is a compilation of four previously introduced bills, we were quite disappointed that our members did not have the opportunity to weigh in on the language before it was introduced."  https://bit.ly/335gE6F

From Montrose County Commissioners:
"This Board has never taken a formal position on the CORE Act nor has such a formal position been solicited by the proponents of the bill."  https://bit.ly/2pklGhd

With broad local community consensus, the Colorado delegation has been successful in protecting public lands and passing balanced bills that address the unique needs of all Coloradans. The same cannot be said of the CORE Act in it's current form.

For months we have been told the CORE Act has broad local support by the communities most impacted by it. Previous bills in CO with that kind of support have had no trouble earning bipartisan support, most recently, Hermosa Creek and Chimney Rock Nat'l Monument.

Colorado’s 3rd District however is the district where most of his bill would have an impact, and I would be remiss if I didn’t speak out on behalf of some of my constituents who have yet to have their voices heard or their issues addressed in this process.
I applaud the CORE Act’s sponsor, and my Colorado colleague Joe Neguse, for his passion to protect public lands in Colorado. We share that passion.

I am optimistic that we can find a balanced public lands bill that reflects all these communities, but it can’t happen if one side is left out of the conversation from the beginning. More outreach needs to happen, negotiations need to take place, and compromises need to be made.

There is no doubt that the CORE Act has the support of many Coloradans in communities around the state. It is just as important to listen to the supporters of this bill as it is to listen to the input of Western Coloradans who are also affected by this bill.

You can read our letter here: https://tipton.house.gov/media/press-releases/tipton-members-colorado-delegation-send-letter-rockies-regarding-mlb-milb …

It is my sincere hope that the MLB continues to champion its work on promoting baseball in smaller communities as these discussions begin, and I am glad to be joined by my Colorado colleagues in showing our support of the Minor League teams in our great state!

This relationship with the MLB has allowed for fans to enjoy baseball in their hometowns & watch players that eventually played on the squads like the Blake Street Bombers, the 2007 World Series team, and the perpetual all-stars that fill the roster today.
Since their inaugural season in 1993, the @Rockies have brought new life to baseball enthusiasm not only in the Mile High City, but also in smaller communities like Grand Junction.

This week, we learned of a proposal from the @MLB that would restructure the existing partnership with the @MiLB which could negatively impact more than 40 Minor League teams, like the @GJRockies and the @VibesBaseball.
